column4: Natural sand, arid or lean, in which the grains do not adhere together
billon silver (Billon refers to a mixed metal used in coinage, consisting of gold or silver with a preponderating admixture of a baser metal.)
the compound of ground silver with which gilding or “silvering” is done.

In this period, “artiste” could mean skilled artisan, a Master of Arts (the university title), and was just beginning to be used in the sense of “creative artist,” as it is today. We chose to translate as “artist,” but this older connotation of artisanal skill should be kept in mind.
ground (of a painting or for gilding)
unit of measurement, equivalent to an ell, i.e. 2–4 feet.
azure (the color, or various pigments of that color)
jewel (mostly but not necessarily a ring)

column4: basan (sheep-skin tanned in oak- or larch-bark; distinguished from roan, which is tanned in sumach)
to batter, to mount the battery
In Ms. Fr. 640, this term refers to an impermeable layer laid down on cloth in order to paint the cloth without the paint soaking through
flashing (in metal casting: a defect produced by the metal penetrating where it should not, especially at the joint of a two-part mold)
billon (mixed metal used in coinage, consisting of gold or silver with a preponderating admixture of a baser metal)
one who makes and sells bibelots, i.e. small curios or trinkets
a poorly fortified town, fort, or place
brown pigment derived from the tarry soot of burned, resinous wood and beechwood

column4: grain (cereal in general, not wheat as in modern French)
Meaning uncertain. Could refer to a variety of gran or or a way of processing it.
bushel (a cylindrical vessel used for grain)
Gallicised spelling of the Lating "bolus armeni", i.e. armenian bole

A status conferred by the French king in the Ancien Régime, from the late medieval period onwards, granting privileges and financial aid in exchange for military manpower and taxes. "Bonne ville" thus usually referred to a city of a certain size and degree of fortification.
ring (standard part of the structure of a cannon)
ring of the breech (“base ring” in modern terminology)
ring in the middle (“trunnion ring” in modern terminology)
ring of the mouth (“muzzle ring” in modern terminology)
liquid dip used by goldsmiths to clean silver of tarnish (now often called “pickle” in English--a heated mixture of vinegar and salt)
The author-practitioner envisions this as a place of making and selling goods as well as trading knowledge
Arm defense comprising pauldron and vambrace, called a "brassart" in English in the 19th century.
brazilwood (a red wood used for dyeing)
Plaster for horses, made with armenian bole
small bugloss (Anchusa arvensis, a hairy herbaceous plant of the family Boraginaceae, typically with blue flowers)
Meaning uncertain. Possibly a substance for whitening silver.
frail, a kind of basket made of rushes.
quadran, something that is square in shape

calamine, a yellow mineral substance that looks like gold and which fire consumes but does not melt. Also the heavier soil of brass, or copper, which comes out of the sparkles and smoke that arise from the furnace and cleave of the roof and upper sides of the house, wherein it has melted
barrel (hollow instrument, part of a furnace)

column8: BL, Ms Additional 63649 | Not fowler (just used in a naval context), Robert Norton, The Gunner, 1628, p.57

column4: cape, woman's cap or sleeveless cloak
thick paper upon which painters draw
column11: Ms uses "carton" mostly as a casting material.

column4: full charge, paper case containing shot but no powder charge which goes into the barrel as a whole
posnet, small metal pot or vessel for boiling, with a handle and three feet
cavity, hollow (female mold or concave part of the mold that forms the relief in the molded object)
Kind of secondary mold. A cast of something, which in turn will be used as a mold
ash from Acre, alkaline ash from St Jean d'Acre in the Levant used in glassmaking
calcined chalk and charcoal that crucibles are made of, and shop sweepings (dross, etc) in a goldsmith's shop

column4: method of melting and purifying metals in ashes
a circle of clay around a mold presumably for consolidation
long stick on which the sword is laid down and attached in order to furbish it
watering pot, earthenware tool similar to the spout of a watering can
the top part of an alembic
small irregularities or crust-like covering that appear when the metal is cast
coals or embers of a fire
to overcharge, to run too violently, like a military charge
to saturate (ink), to charge (dye, possibly adding weight to the silk), to apply or cover (gilding and metalwork)
to weigh down (sand weighing down the flower in preserving flowers)

column4: power of fire, expulsion of fire (amount of powder in an arquebus)
grape variety from the Charentes region
donner un chaulde, to give a heat (used by goldsmiths, glass-makers and iron workers)
to heat, to raise the temperature of an object. Can be contrasted with "cuire" and "recuire"
coppersmith, tinker, kettlemaker, depending on the context
chafing dish, a vessel to hold burning charcoal or other fuel, for heating anything placed upon it, a portable grate
measure unit Parisian half-pint, according to Cot. "almost as big as our whole one"
royal cement, accrding to Cot. "an excellent cement, or solder, used by goldsmiths"
modelling wax, A-P defines it as "white wax mixed with plenty of ceruse or blanc de plomb" Also mentioned as a "counterfeit diamond"
chisel or scissors when inflected in plural form
to chase, rather than to literally chisel (to repair the surface of a cast)
small serrated chisel (a sculptor's tool, also known as gradine or claw chisel)
cittern, an instrument of the lute family
civet, a substance taken from the glands of the civet-cat
not heavy nor dense, but light and clear
a sheet of gold or gilded metal
glue made of wheat flour, stationer's paste
paste glue, also known as paste, wheatpaste or flour paste
fish glue, also known as mouth glue or water glue, since is can be moistened and made adhesive by wetting with the mouth
hide glue, glue made from collage-containing remains of four footed animals (skins, hooves, etc)
strong glue, probably made from collagen-containing remains of four-footed animals
columbine, of a red-violet color similar to the neck of a pigeon

to counterfeit, the A-P distinguishes between imiter and contrefaire, with imiter meaning to make a representation of something (a thing or scene), and “contrefaire” to mimic a (valuable) material in (more available) materials, such as “coral contrefaict” and “jaspe contrefaict.”

cupel, a small flat circular porous vessel with a shallow
depression in the middle made of pounded bone ash, pressed into shape by a mold, and
used in assaying gold and silver with lead.

a similarly shape test or moveable
hearth of the reverberatory furnace in which silver is separated from lead cupellation.
to keep flat, of hairs on an animal
column19: too specific to include in glossary? how many instances in ms?

column4: copperas, protosulphates of copper, iron and zinc, distinguished as blue, green, and white copperas respectively. Etymologically it belonged properly to the copper salt, but in English use, when undistinguished by attribute or context, it has always been most commonly, and is now exclusively, applied to green copperas, the proto-sulphate of iron or ferrous sulphate, also called green vitriol, used in dyeing, tanning, and making ink

a semi-precious stone that has a red-hue. What it is precisely
in modern terms is not clear, but this translation retains the ambiguity
horn, a translucent material. Most likely bovine in the context of Ms Fr 640, as cow horn grows in layers that can be split into thinner sheets
retort, according to Cot. "a kind of bending Limbecke (like a Bagpipe) of glasse, varnished, and leaded within; used for th’extracting of oyles out of hard and drie things, as wood, mettalls, etc"
to subject metal to hot-working or currying steel?
currier, One whose trade is the dressing and colouring of leather after it is tanned
a stuff that is used for stuffing, wadding, or padding. It can be made of wool and other materials (cotton, the plant, eventually took on the name of the stuff)
layer, coat of paint, varnish, etc.
to pour, to run through, sometimes in the sense of strain of filter
substance to make metals flow more easily, a flux or liquifier
clamps, metal parts used to hold molds together
toadstone, according to DMF "petrified tooth of the earless seal, originally thought to come from the head of the toad. It was used as a precious stone, and to detect the presence of poison"
filth, it may be the scale resulting from excessive heat when melting metal
cristallo glass, similar to that made in Murano
crocus of iron, a red pigment made by dissolving iron filings in nitric acid or vinegar
cuirass, a defense for the torso, consisting of breastplate and backplate
bastard culverin, gun weighting 35 quintals and armed with a 25 pounds cannonball
column8: OED | Norton Robert, The gunner , 1628, p. 157.

column4: demi-culverin, gun weighting 30 quintals and armed with a 20 pounds cannonball
column8: OED | Norton Robert, The gunner , 1628, p. 157.

column4: to cook, or to transform by the action of heat.

column4: to damask, to apply to a cloth patterns in the style of damask
to decrepitate, to calcine or roast (a salt or mineral) until it no longer crackles in the fire
to macerate, allay, or soften, by steeping; also to thin
unit of currency (1/12 of a sol, 1/240 of a livre)
unit of weight (1/785 of a kilogram)
ware, from denerée (ware which has the value of a denier)
tooth, (wolf or dog tooth, used as a tool for burnishing gold and silver)
some kind of grinding tool that works on a wheel to clean the inside of pewter dishes and bowls (maybe a lathe type instrument)

delicate or thin, “delicate” or “thin”, according to context 
délié is related etymologically to delicate (Lat. delicatus)
released, easily released (based on shape of the object used for molding), as defined by the A-P in p114r_1
to release, speaking of the mold releasing the cast

to distemper (painting), technique that involves a variety of binding media such as egg, glue, size. Not to confuse with tempera, which refers more narrowly to a technique using egg yolk as the binding medium
at discretion, as much as is needed
smooth, of set sands being cut
measurement unit, according to Cot "a hands breadth, or the breadth of four fingers"
a jewel made of two pieces joined together
drug, any substance used as an ingredient in various making processes

rock water (the author-practitioner defines this term on 11r: eau de roche, qu’ilz appellent, c’est une eau distillée des mines où l’azur ou vert d’azur se trouve, qui naturellement distille par les veines de la montaigne ou qui est par alambic distillée par des pierres mineralles d’azur ou cuivre – "it is a water distilled from mines where azure or vert d'azur is found, which distills naturally through the veins of the mountain or is distilled through an alembic from mineral stones of azure or copper.")
water in which bread has been boiled
electrum (an alloy of gold and silver thought to have occult properties, such as protection from poison)

the space between or middle part

quillon block (part of the hilt of a sword)
escutcheon (escutcheon-shaped mark on a cannon which may indicate the powder charge)
a way of grafting trees (hanter en escusson)

donner fort de chasse, to excite
breach (made by an explosive, e.g. a petard)
falconet (according to the author-practitioner, a cannon weighing four quintals and 10 pans long, with shot weighing 1.25 lb and a powder charge of half a lb)

figurated (decorated with human or animal figures as opposed to abstract ornaments)
figure (where clearly referring to a material object)
fine (in the case of metals, this means pure; in other cases it is often unclear whether it refers to quality or purity)
flower (the whole plant or the bloom)
Meaning uncertain, possibly "a thunder-stone, a kind of stone wherewith Cutlers furbish their blades” (Cotgrave)

Indigo pigment from the dark blue foam and scum on the surface of the woad (or indigo) dyeing vat. Flouret is probably the same thing. See also Indigo (cf PG). Also: fleurs de pastel (pastel being another term often used interchangeably with woad, as noted in Cotgrave under “Guesde”).  Kirby et al., p. 449, call it “florey”. Also see “fleuree” (fol. 73r), acc. to Cotgrave the scum of boiling any flowers.

violent fire (i.e. which is blown up into live flames. "En termes de Chymie, on appelle feu de chasse, un feu violent, quand on a ouvert tous les registres d’un fourneau. Delaulne, Dictionnaire universel, 1721.)

gabion (a large basket-like container filled with rocks and used as protection for gunners)

gate (in casting, the place where the molten metal is poured into the mold)
jet (a hard black variety of coal that takes a brilliant polish and is used for jewellery, ornaments, etc.)

column4: to glaze (with oil paint, to achieve a glassy surface)

column4: egg glair (egg white beaten with water and strained)

column8: Cotgrave: "an earthen bole; a stone cup, or jug"

column4: gum ammoniac (also known as “ammoniac gum” or “ammoniacum”. A complex gum/oil/resin mixture obtained from the stems of carrot family plant, Dorema ammoniacum, native to Iran and India)
tragacanth gum (a natural gum obtained from the dried sap of several species of Middle Eastern legumes of the genus Astragalus)
Meaning uncertain, possibly lower quality gum (gomme + -iche, suffix for lower quality)
fatty (i.e. soft, malleable, or rich, according to material or context)
great metals (unclear which metals this refers to:  on fol. 156r the ms speaks of lead “and the other great metals,” but on fol. 134v, it speaks of the casting of gold)
scratch-brush (either a large wire brush or a small, pencil-shaped brush now commonly used in clockmaking)
a particular type of potters' clay or earth for making stoneware vessels, or the stoneware vessels themselves

Meaning uncertain, probably a smaller type of ingot than the 'saumon', and more convenient to sell. See eg. Dictionnaire universel de Commerce (1742), which likens "grile" to "saumon", although to the AP these are clearly different (on fol. 28v).
to grip, to stick, to take hold
name given to several species of squirrel and, by extension, to their fur
coarse, thick, large (of sand, cloth etc.)

large wares (grosserie in this period often also referred to work done in bulk (see Littré), but this is not what seems to be implied in the ms. See also Cennini's use of grosseria as opposed to minuteria, suggesting large wares as opposed to small delicate ones. Cennini’s translator Ashbee: “metal work of the larger sort, as opposed to minuteria. Our term, hammered hollow ware, would partly express it. It mainly included the beating of large vessels into shapes, but it did not exclude the processes of casting.”)
column8: Ac. 1835-1932 | GRANDJEAN, Orfèvr. XIXe s., 1962, p. 22 | Littré

column4: muzzle (of a gun, to distinguish from bouche)

guede woad (as distinct from pastel or "pastel woad"; it is unclear whether the author means the two terms to be entirely synonymous. Cotgrave: “Many of the French dyers call the courser sort of stuffe Guesde, and the finer Pastel; most writers confound them.”

pig (in metalwork, a large ingot of iron cast straight from the blast furnace. In English, the term "pig" is still widely used and includes iron and nonferrous materials cast into sand or metal moulds provided that it is intended for remelting before use. In French "gueuse" is restricted to virgin iron.)
gimlet (a small tool with a screw point, grooved shank, and cross handle for boring holes)
alidade (pivoted sight or pointer, typically part of an astrolabe)
hackbut (used interchangeably with "arquebus" in the period. Cotgrave also has “caliver”, which is a small smooth-bore long firearm)
arquebus à croc, or wall gun (a gun with a hook preventing the recoil by steadying it on a wall or battlement)
haqueton (a now obsolete English term designating a jerkin or plated leather jacket)

column4: oil of sulfur (vitriol or sulfuric acid)
keep Fr. — [has this been looked into?] Defined in 137r

to imitate (the author-practitioner apparently distinguishes between imiter and contrefaire, with imiter meaning to make a representation of something (a thing or scene), and contrefaire to mimic a (valuable) material in (more available) materials, such as coral contrefaict and jaspe contrefaict.
impalpable (used as technical term for very finely made powder
impostume (Cotgrave: "An inwards swelling full of corrupt matter")
a shade of red (Cotgrave: "a deep, rich, or bright carnation")

a literary word, essentially meaning ‘dishonourableness’. Similar word ‘honorificabilitudinitatibus’ used in Shakespeare’s Love Labours Lost (Act V, Scene I) and many other sources. Also found in Dictionaries from the late 15th/16thC. Although the trick is in Jean Prevost (54v-56v), he does not use this term.
column8: Loves Labours Lost ed. H. H. Furness(1906), 216-7.

column4: injection (not necessarily intravenous injection, but any administration of liquid medicine into any part of the body, e.g. enemas etc)

column8: Corneille (Dict. des arts, 1694): "Pierre pretieuse, qui par son feu semble tenir du rubis. Elle en differe pourtant en ce que sa couleur est moins chargée; elle ressemble aussi à l’Amethyste, tirant quelque peu sur le violet. (...) Toutes ces sortes de Pierres sont Orientales, apportées de Cananor, Calecut ou Cambaïe."

column4: Floral Games, a poetry competition in Renaissance Toulouse, in which lifecast flowers were given as prizes
double handful (i.e. the amount that can be cupped in two hands)
Having perforations or holes, pierced; spec. designating an ornamental openwork pattern
a natural day, i.e., 24 hours. In contrast to a jour artificiel (a tradesman’s day from sunrise to sunset) or jour civil (also 24 hours, but starting according to the custom of the place or nation)

Meaning uncertain; "vieulx K" occurs twice in the manuscript (fol. 86v and 147v), and both instances are associated with a silver-copper alloy. Silver-copper alloy was used in minting coins, where it was known as billon. The abbreviation K might thus indicate a coin, perhaps the German Kreuzer which was abbreviated K and was made of silver-copper alloy up until the seventeenth century.
latten (likely a copper, tin, zinc, and sometimes lead alloy. There is debate amongst scholars about the definition of brass or laiton in modern French vs. bronze, both of which are copper alloys)
potin latten (presumably latten made with potin, an alloy of copper and tin, usually with lead and zinc, used by ancient Celtic peoples for making coins)
plate (of metal. In plated armor, overlapping plates or bands connected by rivets or internal leathers to achieve articulation)
burdock (likely the genus Arctium, previously called Lappa)
narrow-leaved dock or sorrel, Rumex acetosa
lake (pigment produced by a lake process; usually a red one. From lac, a red colorant made from a variety of organic materials)
(tool used to charge guns or the equivalent measure of powder)

to wash (for pigments, this refers to a process now known as levigation)
sweepings from the furnace and shop floor of metalworkers
bundle (a quantity of glass for sale)
line (often a measurement; Cotgrave says a twelfth of an inch; in the ms on fol. 22r it is defined as a twelfth of a king's foot)
livre (any of a number of coins or units of account used in France)

to lute (cover the outside of the vessel with lute to seal and protect the vessel from the heat)
liquid binder used in sand molding
marcasite (bronze-yellow mineral consisting of iron disulphide, also known as pyrite. Palissy defines marcasites as imperfect metals, sometimes formed in a square fashion, like dice)

possibly a wild peach, Prunus persica var. persica Batsch. Peaches in general are called pesches in Fr. 640. This is a big yellow peach also known as “Pavie” in mod. Fr. Often just called peach in English today (vs "melicotony" in the 18th c.)

millet (a variety of common barley, of which a very coarse bread is made, especially in the South of France)

morion (open-faced helmet with cheek pieces and a brim, either with a comb or a point on top)
mortar (grinding tool, as in mortar and pestle)

petard (artillery. Note that mortier and the English “mortar” refer to an artillery piece which fires at high angles; BUT the author-practitioners also uses “mortier” for a bomb which in English was known as a petard)

noyau is used in Ms. Fr. 640 to mean “core,” that is, the inner block in a mold that allows casting a figure with a hollow core or center. Another name for such a “core” in French is âme. Félibien and Cellini use the two terms interchangeably (anima and nocciolo in Italian). The author-practitioner uses “ame” once on fol. 124r to mean core, but he seems to be contrasting it to the “noyau” by which he seems to mean the outer plaster mold. He contrasts molding and casting “en chassis” with that done “en noyau,” meaning molding with plaster either in one-piece or multi-piece molds.

to tranform again by the action of heat. In f.111r, the author defines "recuire" as the process of turning a mold red for the second time (“Faire pour la seconde fois rougir”). He contrasts this process to drying (“desseicher”) metals. Similarly, on a margin note of f.118v, “recuire” is defined as “turning a frame red,” a process similar to what “is done for gold and silver.”

While the a-p aften uses “recuire” in its generic meaning (i.e., to put again something to the fire), the 9th edition of the DAF specifies that the verb is also employed in many arts to designate a specific heating treatment which craftsmen use in order to “perfect their craft” or “make it more durable.” Goldsmiths, for example, restitute the desired malleability and ductility of their objects by reheating or annealing them. Glassblowers use a special furnace to reheat the glass lest it shatters. This process can be translated in English as “annealing” or “tempering,” according to the context. (See Ashbee’s translations of “ricuocere” in Benevenuto Cellini’s Two Treatises.)
While a “brique recuite” is a refired brick, on 94r, it is probably being used to mean “annealed iron wire”.

“Recuire can be contrasted to “cuire,” which is mostly used in the context of food preparation, the verb “cuire” refers more broadly to the transformation of an object by the action of heat. Similarly, “chauffer” means to increase an object’s temperature, but not necessarily to transform it by the action of heat.
regulus, according to OED: metal separated from a mineral or ore by smelting or reduction, as the first stage of purification

reverberation. In a furnace using reflected heat (four à reverberation), the fire is separated from the hearth and the air reverberates throught the chamber, in order to get the chamber hotter while avoiding the material to catch fire
